lg.l: Beautiful art thou, Auckland, Auckland. Tāmaki Makaurau/Auckland is located in the north of the North Island of New Zealand and was the capital of the colony from 1841-1865. without measure;
Thou city of the sea. City of the sea. The centre of Tāmaki Makaurau/Auckland is located on an isthmus between the Waitematā Harbour and Manukau Harbour.
Thy terraced slopes Terraced slopes. Many of the numerous volcanic cones in the Auckland region were terraced in the course of Māori occupation prior to colonisation. rise swelling from the wavelets
That murmur unto thee.
The sounding dirges of the stormy ocean
Approach thee not anear;
For many isles, Many isles. Several islands in the Hauraki Gulf are visible from Auckland. their adamantine bulwarks,
For thy protection roar.
And, surging round the tri-peaked Rangitoto, Tri-peaked Rangitoto. Rangitoto Island is a volcanic cone located in the Hauraki Gulf.
The ocean tide doth sweep;
Till, in the bosom of thy land-locked harbour
It softly falls asleep.
Beautiful art thou, Auckland, when the day dawn,
Transfused with pearly light,
Reveals, through the soft haze of liquid opal,
Thy beauty to our sight.
Beautiful art thou, Auckland, when the sunset
Its glory doth unfold;
And o’er the purple ranges throws its splendour
Of crimson and of gold,
Lighting thee up with all the tints of cloudland,
In rich and mellow glow;
While myriad casements, in the molten glory,
Like myriad sunlets shew.
The first bright kisses of the morning greet thee,
And silver-top each hill.
The midday sun shines on thy leafy coverts,
And sparkles on each rill.
The evening sun folds thee in mellow glory
Of ruddy, golden light;
And fondly gazeth on thee long, ‘ere sinketh
O’er thee the shades of night.
And then, fair Luna flings her silver radiance
Upon each rounded hill;
And, from the realms of Elfland thou seem’st starting,
So silver bright and still.
Man! dost thou choose the city’s hum and bustle? City’s hum and bustle. The census of 1881 calculated the population of Auckland and its suburbs as 30,952.
Thitherward thou canst go;
The human tide, through streets arterial, surges
In restless, onward flow.
Man! dost thou choose to gaze upon the ocean?—
Then, from each swelling hill,
On land-locked harbour, and on ocean surges,
There, thou canst gaze thy fill.
Man! dost thou choose to seek the leafy coverts
Of ferny, bosky glade?—
Such glades there are for thee, in rich profusion,
With deep, umbrageous shade.
If thou preferrest panoramic glory,
Thy roving eyes may glance
From many a lofty hill, unhinder’d sweeping
O’er rich and wide expanse.
There, thou can’st study sweet, untrammell’d Nature,

Or rich, but trammell’d Art; Art. Alfred Sharpe he began to exhibit watercolour paintings in Auckland in the 1870s, and would publish “Hints for Landscape Students in Water-Colour” as a series of essays in 1880-82.
Of all that thou canst wish, in outward feature,
There is a counterpart.
Beautiful Auckland! The sojourner leaveth
Thy shores with fond regret;
While those who daily see thy changing beauty
Think thou art peerless yet.
Yea, thou art peerless; spreading in thy beauty
On Waitemata’s hem;
Like some rich jewel, set within the wreathings
Of Nature’s diadem.
Thy smiling cottages and mansions cluster
Along the sunny shore;
And Art and Nature, hand in hand, have crown’d thee
A queen Queen. Auckland had acquired the nickname of the “Queen City” by the 1870s. for evermore.
